"Solving" human language is just another entry on the long list of things people assume can only be done by insanely intelligent beings, like chess, or image recognition etc., and pretend like human level AGI is here because we managed to solve those problems.

- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months

Congratulations on your goal of becoming a fireman! Building up your physical fitness is an important aspect of preparing for this career. Here are a few additional suggestions to help you prepare for the physical requirements:

Mix up your training: While it's important to work on your endurance, it's also important to include other types of training in your routine. Incorporating strength training, such as weight lifting, bodyweight exercises, or resistance band workouts, can help you build the muscular endurance and strength needed to perform firefighting tasks.

Stay hydrated: Proper hydration is important for any workout, but especially for endurance training. Make sure to drink plenty of water before, during, and after your workouts to keep your body hydrated and functioning at its best.

Incorporate interval training: Interval training involves alternating periods of high-intensity exercise with periods of rest or lower-intensity exercise. This type of training can help improve your speed and endurance, which will be beneficial for the 2.4km run.

Stretch regularly: To prevent injury and improve your flexibility, it's important to stretch regularly. Focus on stretching your hamstrings, quads, calves, and hips, as these muscles are heavily used during running.

Consider working with a trainer: A certified personal trainer can help you develop a workout plan that is tailored to your specific needs and goals. They can also help ensure that you are using proper form during exercises and provide additional guidance and motivation.

Remember to take it slow and steady as you work towards your goal, and be sure to give your body the rest and recovery it needs. Good luck!

>>69989830
There are 'after c25k' programs, but it really isn't necessary at that point, because you should be able to handle some running without snapping your shit, but fancy workouts really aren't needed, just to get to 10k. Oldschool approach by Lydiard:

>Running continuously for longish periods of time helps to develop existing capillary beds and also creates new ones. This results in greater capacity to utilize oxygen and eliminate waste products. Greater muscular endurance comes in turn.
>If you are accustomed to running for, say, 15 minutes daily, the best approach for developing stamina is to increase duration every third day to about 30 minutes. On the days in between, revert to 15 minutes for two days until the improvement in stamina is apparent. This approach to training should be continued progressively until it is possible to run for an hour or longer, i.e., an increase of the usual daily run, with the weekly schedule including two or three longer runs of 30 minutes or so for two days, then a longer run of 45-60 minutes on the third day. This way, endurance improves quickly.
>When you can run freely for up to an hour or more, you should be able to participate in Fun Runs and other competitions of an aerobic nature without fear of developing a problem. If racing is contemplated, anaerobic training becomes necessary, in order to develop the capacity to withstand oxygen debt.

Once you reached 60min and assuming you aren't severely overweight or a 40+ boomer, you should be at 10k anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Oreo edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Self-indulgent snackers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69986610
Unsweetened seltzer water, my friend. You get the fizzy fix without the sugar. They are best if they are extremely cold, especially over ice. The flavor comes out best when it's cold. Be sure to check ingredients for sweeteners.

Some good brands are Bubly, La Croix, and Waterloo. The Bubly orange, cherry, and blackberry all legit taste like soda when they're ice cold.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69986610
>>69987739
Forgot to add- you can go to the liquor section of the grocery store and find straight seltzer water (no flavor) in 1 liter bottles for about a dollar. Check the ingredients again here because it'll be right next to club soda, etc which isn't the same thing. Anyway you can get that and then use the little flavor squirts in it (like Mio or generic equivalent) and it's tasty and zero calorie. It's also good just by itself.

For most people 1/2/3/4 will put you on the cusp of actually looking like you are strong with your clothes on. Strength doesn’t correlate with physique for two reasons
>you can be strong and very fat, which looks like shit
>you can get stronger without getting bigger when you are just starting out or for a short period of time.
But eventually if you can bench 300 pounds and have low body fat, you will have big looking muscles. The idea that you won’t is retarded.

In the end it’s about time. Just pick a vetted program and do it for several years before you try to nerd your way into a good physique. Eat high protein, sleep, keep calories capped, do this for years. And don’t go back to the drawing board until you can do 1/2/3/4. Until then, you are still basically a beginner.

>I'd use butter, but the high temperature nature of stir frying makes it burn.

Don't use butter. You can use ghee which is butter with the milk proteins removed and has a much higher smoke point, or lard (bacon fat), or tallow (cow fat). All are very tasty, affordable, and with high smoke points. Other oils like avocado have much higher smoke points but are much more expensive and come in tiny amounts.

>>69987201
>What was your method
Benched 2x times a week, OHP on a third day. Would probably be more efficient to drop that and bench x3, but it's more tricky in regards to programming sustainable volume/intensity and not BTFO'ing your shoulders.
Milked beginner re-gains for a few weeks, I started at 155lbs for 7 reps. Just adding weight and linearly PR'ing every session at different 3-8 rep ranges got me to a 210lbs 1RM. The way I failed the subsequent 225lbs told me that pecs are the weak point.
With that I ran an actual % program, Greg Nuckols 2-day beginner bench with high rep wide grip benching on the second day. 4 week program with increasing volume/intensity, half week deload at week 4 then a new 1RM attempt towards the end of the week. Hit 225lbs for a nice clean rep with a little left in the tank. Going to rerun it and aiming for 235lbs+ in 3.5 weeks time.
Otherwise I took nutrition and sleep seriously, but it wasn't perfect. I also spent some time refining my technique. I don't use a crazy arch and I am still figuring out leg drive, just a consistent setup and technique.

Judo and boxing are IMO the best for street fighting against an untrained attacker because the most likely things an untrained aggressor will try is to
1. Punch you
2. Grab your upper body
Judo and boxing train exactly these things. If someone tries to sucker punch you, if you focus on slipping punches a lot, you’ll at least see it coming. If someone tries to grab your shirt or wrist, as a good judoka you’ll be used to breaking grips away while keeping your balance and throwing. Lastly judo trains break falling the most, which is absolutely crucial on concrete as hitting your head = ko

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69989660
While you absolutely will never encounter somebody wearing something as grippable as a gi in da streetz, you will rarely encounter someone with nothing to grip at all. Honestly the biggest difficulty isn’t gripping close to their core, you can get a fairly dominant position around the neck even if they’re shirtless (obviously worse than holding onto a gi). But if they don’t have long sleeves on it’s much more difficult to grab their wrist, especially if they’re swearing. It’s not a totally different world to grabbing their sleeve but it gives you less control, brings the range closer, and makes it easier for them to break your grip.
What I don’t understand is why people think this suddenly makes judo useless. The exact same applies to the other guy; you’re not walking around in a gi either. If some untrained retard can’t take you down in a gi he’s not going to be able to do so nogi either.

Basically all elite conventional pullers round their back. The cope used to be "b-but they only round their thoracic" but the truth is most of them just round the entire fuckin thing cause the leverage gains are undeniable. Proper bracing and strong erectors prevent shifts in spinal position during the lift which is where most injuries happen.

That being said, most people are not elite powerlifters and you can certainly get strong with a neutral back, you just probably won't reach whatever peak you could otherwise.

Preacher curl is especially dangerous as the angle of the bench maximises the moment arm when the tendon is in the fully stretched position, while fully pronating your arms like that puts an enormous amount of additional strain on the biceps tendon at just the correct angle to rip it right off the bone. If he'd done it standing, or with an EZ or hammer curl bar, then it probably wouldn't have happened. Preacher curls are the kind of exercise that should only ever be done for high reps.

>I go to 1 or 2 reps before failure on every set so I don't know what else to do. How can it be "not much of a workout"?
You do ABABAB so you're only giving any given muscle group one day to rest. The next time you hit said muscle group it hasn't fully recovered and had a chance to grow so your "1 or 2 reps before failure" is much lower than it should be. Just because you aren't feeling DOMS doesn't mean your muscles aren't tired and need to rest. Do at most 4 day ABxABxx and give your body the rest it needs to grow properly and push harder.

>>69983661
>>69983768
For ABABABx it can actually work imo, I did the ‘Best damn program for natural lifters’ for a few blocks and it worked well. Pretty much maxes out the volume to frequency and recovery ratio. It’s a meme name I know, but worthy read. It’s basically one work set for each of 4 exercises a day (some isolation) to failure but you do rest-pause or Myo reps or whatever to reach close to or past failure in some form, pull/push split.

It’s good to change up frequency between blocks though from a meta perspective, from the general research I think the common trend is that novel stimulus works really well for a few months then you adapt and stimulus declines a bit. I fee personally I find a balance of hitting failure and having twice a week frequency. I like sometimes to do a massive rest-pause set to slow rep drops sets until I’m way past failure, but the recovery time seems too long if I have to wait a week to feel strong again. I recommend the 6 day a week as a good medium, or something different, but personally also stick to upper/lower splits for time efficiency or sometimes full body to be able to add more cardio/sports days.

I keep running into a recurring issue however. I have had two girls that I held very strong feelings for that it ended up not working out with. One quickly became a friend of mine, but since confessing my feelings (stupid idea, I know) no longer talks to me and acts pissed when she sees me. The other showed lots of interest but ended up ghosting me. It took me some time to move on beyond them (I’m new to girls even at 24) but here’s the issue:

Any shared hobbies or interests I held with these girls, I feel like I’m not allowed to enjoy since they rejected me. For example, I had a roommate years ago who tried over and over to get me to go to BJJ and rock-climbing with him, and I never did. I’ve been pondering the idea more seriously lately, but the first girl was also heavily into BJJ and rock-climbing, and since she acts the way she did, and pretty much hates me now, I have this block within me that prevents me from even thinking of trying those things out.

There’s other things besides that but that is the most applicable example I can think of. I know logically in my head I should just say “fuck them” and continue to forge my own path, but it’s tough. I’ve found another girl I like and I’m wanting to ask her out but I’m scared of becoming obsessed and repeating the same cycle again.

Brotherman, sorry to hear about your situation. I think we've all had that "block". It's a tough thing to overcome, but luckily it's just psychological. Speaking from personal experience, I found that reminding myself, through mantras and meditation, that activities that I have associated or attach to a person I was attracted to are completely independent of them. I had to remind myself I'm still allowed to enjoy those things with or without those people involved.

You are the master of your life. If you want to do BJJ or rock climbing, literally verbally remind yourself that's what you want to do. And really think about it, and really believe it. Luckily it gets easier after the first bout of such "blocks". WAGMI

posts.com:
/FAST/ #28 Anti-Flab Commando Ed
WAGMI bros

FAQ:
> What do I need to start?
- To keep your hands and food away from your piehole
>Beginner's routine?
Start skipping either breakfast or dinner, track your weight daily with a set weigh-in time. If the progress slows, go from 16:8 to something like 20:4 (four hours to eat) or One Meal A Day (OMAD). GET ELECTROLYTES

>I'm a hamplanet that's new to fasting, can I just jump into 3day+ extended fasting?
-Only if you want to burn muscle mass and lean tissue because you aren't fat-adapted retard
>How can I get fat-adapted?
-Do 16:8 or more daily fasting for about 2 months or do keto for a similar length of time if you don't want to feel you're starving or start losing muscle mass

> I want to do a longer fast, what do I need?
- Snake juice and peace
> What is snake juice?
- 1.5 tbsp salt, 1 tsp potassium chloride (nu-salt, no-salt), magnesium citrate/chloride (optional, check for epsom salts) to 2 liters of water
> I feel hungry!
- You shouldn't feel hungry after the first day, if you do and are new, try switching to keto macros and restarting the fast later

>Recommended macros?
- 70% fat, 25% protein, 5% carbs. Keep carbs below 50g total.
- P:E diet - 50% or more protein, <40% fat <10% carbs

>I'm sub 20bf, want to get lean, but don't want to lose muscle
- OMADEOD
>I'm sub 12% and not sleeping well
eat a tiny protein meal 3 hours before bed on your "full" day of the 48
>I'm gaining weight on OMAD
-You're FUCKING UP, weigh your meal components and record in cronometer (free). Add light cardio or standing or switch to OMEOD so you can continue to eat like fat pig.

>LIFE Fasting Circle Group (group fasting tracker for iOS & Android)
https://lifefastingtracker.app.link/Kf9tSyuowmb
Or Search "/fast/"

Post 'em
>GW (goal weight)
>CW (current weight)
>SW (starting weight)
>height
>fasting schedule

There is no such thing as a repetitive question

from everything I read, lifting and fasting just don't go together.
you can't get any protein, so you could get very little gains or even none at all. and also, there's basically a "switch" in your body that turns it from muscle building mode to muscle breakdown mode. this "switch" is controlled by insulin, so basically when you fast you will always be in a muscle breakdown mode.
all in all, building muscle on a fast is either impossible, or stupidly hard and basically wasting effort. lifting can wait, as long as you don't fast for crazy long time you won't lose much to any muscle

So outside of that I've really just noticed a few major changes in fasting : massively increased libido, my allergies practically disappear, oral thrush is annoying but manageable, my hands and feet are no longer always cold, I've lost a net of 85 lbs since I started but I cycle by the season so it's over 150 lbs now, I have much more energy when fasting, I have annoyingly low blood pressure when fasting bad will get light headed .. there's a few more things of course but this is the bigger ones for me at least.

Yes it's entirely possible to lose that much fat. That's about 6 to 9 days of fasting.

>>69958514
Yes, eating up all my meat, raw milk/cheese, and eggs over Sun-Tues (I abstain Fridays and Saturdays, as well as Wednesday). Tuesday is pancakes for breakfast and a huge ribeye from a local farm for dinner. Anything left from the fridge goes to the dog. I'm doing no meat, dairy, eggs, fish/seafood, and sweeteners, but allowing oils and plain herbal tea. Fasting until sunset every day Mon-Sat. Abstinence only on Sunday, but no fast. Holy Thursday night until after the Easter morning mass is no food at all.

A good source for Christian fasting is A Catholic Life. He's a third order Dominican who has researched Christian fasting extensively. He recently released a book I just bought and received today, but his website has been the one resource I use due to the thoroughness of his work, he specializes in the history of fasting in the Church. Below is his collection of numerous articles, as well as a link to purchase his book, Definitive Guide to Catholic Fasting & Abstinence:

I eat a full and diverse diet every single day, including high quality grains, meats veggies, fruits and beans etc. Have been following this for over 7 years. In 2016 my sister and I made a pact to not drink any soda for the entire year - at the end of the year not only had i cut added sugar from my diet but fast food as well just because i usually go very intense on things, to the point of winning bigtime.
fast forward 7 years and I eat tastier foods than I have ever imagined. I just look at food and making tasty things now, I don't worry about any ingredients I use because they're whole foods and I don't eat anything from boxes.

i make everything scratch, exceptions are things like milk, cheese etc yogurt or other harder to source ingredients that i could not realistically care enough about them because the source would be good enough for me to consider it clean IE organic cacao powder, so i can just make my own chocolate at 90% + instead of buying some shitty ass bar from the store.

this is easy to follow, and I will follow it for the rest of my life.
I bike, hike, run lift mainly dumbbells and do body workouts and movements like yoga.

I am 32 and have enjoyed aging EXTREMELY smoothly compared to watching 75% of my peers start to get health issues, pre-diabetes, back problems, fat, no energy, lethargic etc it's been AMAZING watching people scratch and claw for results when I show them time and time again, literally i have 8+ thousand pics of the food i make and my workouts and my adventures to keep active.

who knows, just takes a real inner fire instead of some magic formula.

the formula IS EASY....

eat right, I mean REALLY EAT RIGHT not some stupid bro diet of only beans rice and broccoli, that's elementary level shit. Healthy eating is an ART and once you learn it you will TRANSFORM what you call "cutting" and bulking from this grueling process into an extremely fluid and EASY to manage process, i have been truly lean/muscular since 2018

>>69986346
>eat generally healthy food (very rarely takeout/fastfood, fried tendies from freezer etc) and focus on a lot of meat/protein
>figure out how much food currently means I get PRECISELY full, no weighed down "full" feeling, no longer hungry, just precisely full
>call this meal size 100%
>eat more to gain weight (for instance 110% of meal size for a slow bulk, 140% for a faster bulk)
>eat less to lose weight (90% for a slow cut, 70% for a faster cut)

It's very simple and I'm sure there is a lot more to it, but this works for my simple autistic brain. And I have always been beach bod ready whenever I wanted to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69979678
This.
Your hunger pains are all mental and come from habit, not hunger. For example, you eat at noon so your brain preps for a noon meal but then if it doesn't get fed it complains with hunger pangs. Let's say you start eating lunch regularly at 2 instead of noon now. You'll no longer get those pains at noon or 1, instead they'll shift to 2.

The pains are fake. If you want to know what your real hunger feels like, do a 24 hour fast while only drinking water. The next day you'll understand what hunger is supposed to feel like. (At least somewhat because you're not really starving.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
if you can do it for 8 reps it isn't a heavy weight, if your goal is muscle mass then just do 3 sets of 8-12 reps. Once you can do 3 sets of 12 reps then up the weight by 5 pounds and drop the reps down to 8. have a 1-2:30minute rest in between sets
for strength 4x5 1x5+ works very well with the 5+ set being as many reps of possible so once you can do 4x5 and at least 1x5 on the last set then up the weight by 5 pounds, if you can't do 4x5 with the new weight for at least 2 workout sessions then drop the weight back down for the next session. have a 3-5 minute rest between sets and this tends to be better for compound movements, I wouldn't do this for bi/tri/abs/calves etc

Some people like to do pyramid sets where you start with a light weight but more reps then work your way up to a heavy set with 1-3 reps.
if your 1rm is 300 you could do:
15reps 100lbs
12 reps 150lbs
8reps 200 lbs
5 reps 250lbs
1-2 reps 285lbs
have 2-3 minutes between sets with up to 5 mins of rest for the last set, again better for compound movements and imo this works really well for deadlift.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69975488
>Which are what?
The rings accomodate for your build, which reduces shoulder/clavicle/sternum stress (Very big factor as some people literally can't do parallel bar dips due to their build, but they can still do ring dips). Due to this reason you can also go much deeper safely, which is generally better for hypertrophy due to weighted stretch. Of course since you need to actively stabilize the rings it's a very good exercise to indirectly strengthen your rotator cuff, which will reduce injury risk on other movements. And of course if you're strong enough you can go into the RTO position at the top, which shortens the pecs even more, something you can't do on regular dips.
>How are they more taxing if they're easier?
Greater absolute load is an independent fatigue factor, and greater absolute loads are necessary on regular dips due to the exercise being easier
>I could never do more than 12 at once so I didn't bother with this when I did them.
Then fatigue probably won't be an issue for you
